text: I could not help however repeatedly observing through the mingled tone of levity and solemnity with which he rapidly descanted upon matters of little importance a certain air of trepidation--a degree of nervous unction in action and in speech--an unquiet excitability of manner which appeared to me at all times unaccountable and upon some occasions even filled me with alarm.
author: EAP

text: Frequently too pausing in the middle of a sentence whose commencement he had apparently forgotten he seemed to be listening in the deepest attention as if either in momentary expectation of a visiter or to sounds which must have had existence in his imagination alone.
author: EAP

text: It was during one of these reveries or pauses of apparent abstraction that in turning over a page of the poet and scholar Politians beautiful tragedy The Orfeo the first native Italian tragedy which lay near me upon an ottoman I discovered a passage underlined in pencil.
author: EAP

text: It was a passage towards the end of the third act--a passage of the most heart-stirring excitement--a passage which although tainted with impurity no man shall read without a thrill of novel emotion--no woman without a sigh.
author: EAP

text: The whole page was blotted with fresh tears; and upon the opposite interleaf were the following English lines written in a hand so very different from the peculiar characters of my acquaintance that I had some difficulty in recognising it as his own--  Thou wast that all to me love For which my soul did pine-- A green isle in the sea love A fountain and a shrine All wreathed with fairy fruits and flowers; And all the flowers were mine.
author: EAP

text: Ah dream too bright to last Ah starry Hope that didst arise But to be overcast A voice from out the Future cries Onward--but oer the Past Dim gulf my spirit hovering lies Mute--motionless--aghast For alas  alas  with me The light of life is oer.
author: EAP

text: No more--no more--no more Such language holds the solemn sea To the sands upon the shore Shall bloom the thunder-blasted tree Or the stricken eagle soar Now all my hours are trances; And all my nightly dreams Are where the dark eye glances And where thy footstep gleams In what ethereal dances By what Italian streams.
author: EAP

text: Alas  for that accursed time They bore thee oer the billow From Love to titled age and crime And an unholy pillow-- From me and from our misty clime Where weeps the silver willow  That these lines were written in English--a language with which I had not believed their author acquainted--afforded me little matter for surprise.
author: EAP

text: I was too well aware of the extent of his acquirements and of the singular pleasure he took in concealing them from observation to be astonished at any similar discovery; but the place of date I must confess occasioned me no little amazement.
author: EAP

text: It had been originally written London and afterwards carefully overscored--not however so effectually as to conceal the word from a scrutinizing eye.
author: EAP

text: I say this occasioned me no little amazement; for I well remember that in a former conversation with a friend I particularly inquired if he had at any time met in London the Marchesa di Mentoni who for some years previous to her marriage had resided in that city when his answer if I mistake not gave me to understand that he had never visited the metropolis of Great Britain.
author: EAP

text: I might as well here mention that I have more than once heard without of course giving credit to a report involving so many improbabilities that the person of whom I speak was not only by birth but in education an Englishman.
author: EAP

text: There is one painting said he without being aware of my notice of the tragedy--there is still one painting which you have not seen.
author: EAP

text: And throwing aside a drapery he discovered a full-length portrait of the Marchesa Aphrodite.
author: EAP

text: Human art could have done no more in the delineation of her superhuman beauty.
author: EAP

text: The same ethereal figure which stood before me the preceding night upon the steps of the Ducal Palace stood before me once again.
author: EAP

text: But in the expression of the countenance which was beaming all over with smiles there still lurked incomprehensible anomaly that fitful stain of melancholy which will ever be found inseparable from the perfection of the beautiful.
author: EAP

text: Her right arm lay folded over her bosom.
author: EAP

text: With her left she pointed downward to a curiously fashioned vase.
author: EAP

text: One small fairy foot alone visible barely touched the earth; and scarcely discernible in the brilliant atmosphere which seemed to encircle and enshrine her loveliness floated a pair of the most delicately imagined wings.
author: EAP

text: My glance fell from the painting to the figure of my friend and the vigorous words of Chapmans Bussy DAmbois quivered instinctively upon my lips  He is up There like a Roman statue  He will stand Till Death hath made him marble  Come he said at length turning towards a table of richly enamelled and massive silver upon which were a few goblets fantastically stained together with two large Etruscan vases fashioned in the same extraordinary model as that in the foreground of the portrait and filled with what I supposed to be Johannisberger.
author: EAP

text: Come he said abruptly let us drink It is early--but let us drink.
author: EAP

text: It is indeed early he continued musingly as a cherub with a heavy golden hammer made the apartment ring with the first hour after sunrise It is indeed early--but what matters it let us drink Let us pour out an offering to yon solemn sun which these gaudy lamps and censers are so eager to subdue And having made me pledge him in a bumper he swallowed in rapid succession several goblets of the wine.
author: EAP

text: To dream he continued resuming the tone of his desultory conversation as he held up to the rich light of a censer one of the magnificent vases--to dream has been the business of my life.
author: EAP

text: I have therefore framed for myself as you see a bower of dreams.
author: EAP

text: In the heart of Venice could I have erected a better You behold around you it is true a medley of architectural embellishments.
author: EAP

text: The chastity of Ionia is offended by antediluvian devices and the sphynxes of Egypt are outstretched upon carpets of gold.
author: EAP

text: Proprieties of place and especially of time are the bugbears which terrify mankind from the contemplation of the magnificent.
author: EAP

text: Once I was myself a decorist; but that sublimation of folly has palled upon my soul.
author: EAP

text: Like these arabesque censers my spirit is writhing in fire and the delirium of this scene is fashioning me for the wilder visions of that land of real dreams whither I am now rapidly departing.
author: EAP

text: He here paused abruptly bent his head to his bosom and seemed to listen to a sound which I could not hear.
author: EAP

text: At length erecting his frame he looked upwards and ejaculated the lines of the Bishop of Chichester  Stay for me there  I will not fail To meet thee in that hollow vale.
author: EAP

text: In the next instant confessing the power of the wine he threw himself at full-length upon an ottoman.
author: EAP

text: A quick step was now heard upon the staircase and a loud knock at the door rapidly succeeded.
author: EAP

text: I was hastening to anticipate a second disturbance when a page of Mentonis household burst into the room and faltered out in a voice choking with emotion the incoherent words My mistress--my mistress--Poisoned--poisoned Oh beautiful--oh beautiful Aphrodite  Bewildered I flew to the ottoman and endeavored to arouse the sleeper to a sense of the startling intelligence.
author: EAP

text: But his limbs were rigid--his lips were livid--his lately beaming eyes were riveted in death.
author: EAP

text: I staggered back towards the table--my hand fell upon a cracked and blackened goblet--and a consciousness of the entire and terrible truth flashed suddenly over my soul.
author: EAP

text: Impia tortorum longos hic turba furores Sanguinis innocui non satiata aluit.
author: EAP

text: Sospite nunc patria fracto nunc funeris antro Mors ubi dira fuit vita salusque patent.
author: EAP

text: Quatrain composed for the gates of a market to be erected upon the site of the Jacobin Club House at Paris.
author: EAP

text: I WAS sick--sick unto death with that long agony; and when they at length unbound me and I was permitted to sit I felt that my senses were leaving me.
author: EAP

text: The sentence--the dread sentence of death--was the last of distinct accentuation which reached my ears.
author: EAP

text: After that the sound of the inquisitorial voices seemed merged in one dreamy indeterminate hum.
author: EAP

text: It conveyed to my soul the idea of revolution--perhaps from its association in fancy with the burr of a mill wheel.
author: EAP

text: This only for a brief period; for presently I heard no more.
author: EAP

text: Yet for a while I saw; but with how terrible an exaggeration I saw the lips of the black-robed judges.
author: EAP

text: They appeared to me white--whiter than the sheet upon which I trace these words--and thin even to grotesqueness; thin with the intensity of their expression of firmness--of immoveable resolution--of stern contempt of human torture.
author: EAP

text: I saw that the decrees of what to me was Fate were still issuing from those lips.
author: EAP

text: I saw them fashion the syllables of my name; and I shuddered because no sound succeeded.
author: EAP

text: I saw too for a few moments of delirious horror the soft and nearly imperceptible waving of the sable draperies which enwrapped the walls of the apartment.
author: EAP

text: And then my vision fell upon the seven tall candles upon the table.
author: EAP

text: At first they wore the aspect of charity and seemed white and slender angels who would save me; but then all at once there came a most deadly nausea over my spirit and I felt every fibre in my frame thrill as if I had touched the wire of a galvanic battery while the angel forms became meaningless spectres with heads of flame and I saw that from them there would be no help.
author: EAP

text: And then there stole into my fancy like a rich musical note the thought of what sweet rest there must be in the grave.
author: EAP

text: The thought came gently and stealthily and it seemed long before it attained full appreciation; but just as my spirit came at length properly to feel and entertain it the figures of the judges vanished as if magically from before me; the tall candles sank into nothingness; their flames went out utterly; the blackness of darkness supervened; all sensations appeared swallowed up in a mad rushing descent as of the soul into Hades.
author: EAP

text: Then silence and stillness night were the universe.
author: EAP

text: I had swooned; but still will not say that all of consciousness was lost.
author: EAP

text: What of it there remained I will not attempt to define or even to describe; yet all was not lost.
author: EAP

text: In the deepest slumber--no In delirium--no In a swoon--no In death--no even in the grave all is not lost.
author: EAP

text: Arousing from the most profound of slumbers we break the gossamer web of some dream.
author: EAP

text: Yet in a second afterward so frail may that web have been we remember not that we have dreamed.
author: EAP

text: In the return to life from the swoon there are two stages; first that of the sense of mental or spiritual; secondly that of the sense of physical existence.
author: EAP

text: It seems probable that if upon reaching the second stage we could recall the impressions of the first we should find these impressions eloquent in memories of the gulf beyond.
author: EAP

text: And that gulf is--what How at least shall we distinguish its shadows from those of the tomb But if the impressions of what I have termed the first stage are not at will recalled yet after long interval do they not come unbidden while we marvel whence they come He who has never swooned is not he who finds strange palaces and wildly familiar faces in coals that glow; is not he who beholds floating in mid-air the sad visions that the many may not view; is not he who ponders over the perfume of some novel flower--is not he whose brain grows bewildered with the meaning of some musical cadence which has never before arrested his attention.
author: EAP

text: Amid frequent and thoughtful endeavors to remember; amid earnest struggles to regather some token of the state of seeming nothingness into which my soul had lapsed there have been moments when I have dreamed of success; there have been brief very brief periods when I have conjured up remembrances which the lucid reason of a later epoch assures me could have had reference only to that condition of seeming unconsciousness.
author: EAP

text: These shadows of memory tell indistinctly of tall figures that lifted and bore me in silence down--down--still down--till a hideous dizziness oppressed me at the mere idea of the interminableness of the descent.
author: EAP

text: They tell also of a vague horror at my heart on account of that hearts unnatural stillness.
author: EAP

text: Then comes a sense of sudden motionlessness throughout all things; as if those who bore me a ghastly train had outrun in their descent the limits of the limitless and paused from the wearisomeness of their toil.
author: EAP

text: After this I call to mind flatness and dampness; and then all is madness--the madness of a memory which busies itself among forbidden things.
author: EAP

text: Very suddenly there came back to my soul motion and sound--the tumultuous motion of the heart and in my ears the sound of its beating.
author: EAP

text: Then again sound and motion and touch--a tingling sensation pervading my frame.
author: EAP

text: Then the mere consciousness of existence without thought--a condition which lasted long.
author: EAP

text: Then very suddenly thought and shuddering terror and earnest endeavor to comprehend my true state.
author: EAP

text: Then a rushing revival of soul and a successful effort to move.
author: EAP

text: And now a full memory of the trial of the judges of the sable draperies of the sentence of the sickness of the swoon.
author: EAP

text: Then entire forgetfulness of all that followed; of all that a later day and much earnestness of endeavor have enabled me vaguely to recall.
author: EAP

text: I reached out my hand and it fell heavily upon something damp and hard.
author: EAP

text: There I suffered it to remain for many minutes while I strove to imagine where and what I could be.
author: EAP

text: It was not that I feared to look upon things horrible but that I grew aghast lest there should be nothing to see.
author: EAP

text: At length with a wild desperation at heart I quickly unclosed my eyes.
author: EAP

text: The intensity of the darkness seemed to oppress and stifle me.
author: EAP

text: I still lay quietly and made effort to exercise my reason.
author: EAP

text: I brought to mind the inquisitorial proceedings and attempted from that point to deduce my real condition.
author: EAP

text: The sentence had passed; and it appeared to me that a very long interval of time had since elapsed.
author: EAP

text: Yet not for a moment did I suppose myself actually dead.
author: EAP

text: Such a supposition notwithstanding what we read in fiction is altogether inconsistent with real existence;--but where and in what state was I The condemned to death I knew perished usually at the autos-da-fe and one of these had been held on the very night of the day of my trial.
author: EAP

text: Had I been remanded to my dungeon to await the next sacrifice which would not take place for many months This I at once saw could not be.
author: EAP

text: Moreover my dungeon as well as all the condemned cells at Toledo had stone floors and light was not altogether excluded.
author: EAP

text: A fearful idea now suddenly drove the blood in torrents upon my heart and for a brief period I once more relapsed into insensibility.
author: EAP

text: Upon recovering I at once started to my feet trembling convulsively in every fibre.
author: EAP

text: I thrust my arms wildly above and around me in all directions.
author: EAP

text: I felt nothing; yet dreaded to move a step lest I should be impeded by the walls of a tomb.
author: EAP

text: Perspiration burst from every pore and stood in cold big beads upon my forehead.
author: EAP

text: The agony of suspense grew at length intolerable and I cautiously moved forward with my arms extended and my eyes straining from their sockets in the hope of catching some faint ray of light.
author: EAP

text: I proceeded for many paces; but still all was blackness and vacancy.
author: EAP

text: It seemed evident that mine was not at least the most hideous of fates.
author: EAP

text: And now as I still continued to step cautiously onward there came thronging upon my recollection a thousand vague rumors of the horrors of Toledo.
author: EAP

text: Of the dungeons there had been strange things narrated--fables I had always deemed them--but yet strange and too ghastly to repeat save in a whisper.
author: EAP

text: Was I left to perish of starvation in this subterranean world of darkness; or what fate perhaps even more fearful awaited me That the result would be death and a death of more than customary bitterness I knew too well the character of my judges to doubt.
author: EAP

text: The mode and the hour were all that occupied or distracted me.
author: EAP

text: It was a wall seemingly of stone masonry--very smooth slimy and cold.
author: EAP

text: I followed it up; stepping with all the careful distrust with which certain antique narratives had inspired me.
author: EAP

text: This process however afforded me no means of ascertaining the dimensions of my dungeon; as I might make its circuit and return to the point whence I set out without being aware of the fact; so perfectly uniform seemed the wall.
author: EAP

text: I therefore sought the knife which had been in my pocket when led into the inquisitorial chamber; but it was gone; my clothes had been exchanged for a wrapper of coarse serge.
author: EAP

text: I had thought of forcing the blade in some minute crevice of the masonry so as to identify my point of departure.
author: EAP

text: The difficulty nevertheless was but trivial; although in the disorder of my fancy it seemed at first insuperable.
author: EAP

text: I tore a part of the hem from the robe and placed the fragment at full length and at right angles to the wall.
author: EAP

text: In groping my way around the prison I could not fail to encounter this rag upon completing the circuit.
author: EAP

text: So at least I thought but I had not counted upon the extent of the dungeon or upon my own weakness.
author: EAP

text: I staggered onward for some time when I stumbled and fell.
author: EAP

text: My excessive fatigue induced me to remain prostrate; and sleep soon overtook me as I lay.
author: EAP

text: Upon awaking and stretching forth an arm I found beside me a loaf and a pitcher with water.
author: EAP

text: I was too much exhausted to reflect upon this circumstance but ate and drank with avidity.
author: EAP

text: Shortly afterward I resumed my tour around the prison and with much toil came at last upon the fragment of the serge.
author: EAP

text: Up to the period when I fell I had counted fifty-two paces and upon resuming my walk I had counted forty-eight more;--when I arrived at the rag.
author: EAP

text: There were in all then a hundred paces; and admitting two paces to the yard I presumed the dungeon to be fifty yards in circuit.
author: EAP

text: I had met however with many angles in the wall and thus I could form no guess at the shape of the vault; for vault I could not help supposing it to be.
author: EAP

text: I had little object--certainly no hope--in these researches; but a vague curiosity prompted me to continue them.
author: EAP

text: Quitting the wall I resolved to cross the area of the enclosure.
author: EAP

text: At first I proceeded with extreme caution for the floor although seemingly of solid material was treacherous with slime.
author: EAP

text: At length however I took courage and did not hesitate to step firmly; endeavoring to cross in as direct a line as possible.
author: EAP

text: I had advanced some ten or twelve paces in this manner when the remnant of the torn hem of my robe became entangled between my legs.
author: EAP

text: In the confusion attending my fall I did not immediately apprehend a somewhat startling circumstance which yet in a few seconds afterward and while I still lay prostrate arrested my attention.
author: EAP

text: It was this--my chin rested upon the floor of the prison but my lips and the upper portion of my head although seemingly at a less elevation than the chin touched nothing.
author: EAP

text: At the same time my forehead seemed bathed in a clammy vapor and the peculiar smell of decayed fungus arose to my nostrils.
author: EAP

text: I put forward my arm and shuddered to find that I had fallen at the very brink of a circular pit whose extent of course I had no means of ascertaining at the moment.
author: EAP

text: Groping about the masonry just below the margin I succeeded in dislodging a small fragment and let it fall into the abyss.
author: EAP

text: For many seconds I hearkened to its reverberations as it dashed against the sides of the chasm in its descent; at length there was a sullen plunge into water succeeded by loud echoes.
author: EAP

text: At the same moment there came a sound resembling the quick opening and as rapid closing of a door overhead while a faint gleam of light flashed suddenly through the gloom and as suddenly faded away.
author: EAP

text: I saw clearly the doom which had been prepared for me and congratulated myself upon the timely accident by which I had escaped.
author: EAP

text: Another step before my fall and the world had seen me no more.
author: EAP

text: And the death just avoided was of that very character which I had regarded as fabulous and frivolous in the tales respecting the Inquisition.
author: EAP

text: To the victims of its tyranny there was the choice of death with its direst physical agonies or death with its most hideous moral horrors.
author: EAP

text: By long suffering my nerves had been unstrung until I trembled at the sound of my own voice and had become in every respect a fitting subject for the species of torture which awaited me.
author: EAP

text: Shaking in every limb I groped my way back to the wall; resolving there to perish rather than risk the terrors of the wells of which my imagination now pictured many in various positions about the dungeon.
author: EAP

text: In other conditions of mind I might have had courage to end my misery at once by a plunge into one of these abysses; but now I was the veriest of cowards.
author: EAP

text: Neither could I forget what I had read of these pits--that the sudden extinction of life formed no part of their most horrible plan.
author: EAP

text: Agitation of spirit kept me awake for many long hours; but at length I again slumbered.
author: EAP

text: Upon arousing I found by my side as before a loaf and a pitcher of water.
author: EAP

text: A burning thirst consumed me and I emptied the vessel at a draught.
author: EAP

text: It must have been drugged; for scarcely had I drunk before I became irresistibly drowsy.
author: EAP

text: A deep sleep fell upon me--a sleep like that of death.
author: EAP

text: How long it lasted of course I know not; but when once again I unclosed my eyes the objects around me were visible.
author: EAP

text: By a wild sulphurous lustre the origin of which I could not at first determine I was enabled to see the extent and aspect of the prison.
author: EAP

text: The whole circuit of its walls did not exceed twenty-five yards.
author: EAP

text: For some minutes this fact occasioned me a world of vain trouble; vain indeed for what could be of less importance under the terrible circumstances which environed me then the mere dimensions of my dungeon But my soul took a wild interest in trifles and I busied myself in endeavors to account for the error I had committed in my measurement.
author: EAP

text: In my first attempt at exploration I had counted fifty-two paces up to the period when I fell; I must then have been within a pace or two of the fragment of serge; in fact I had nearly performed the circuit of the vault.
author: EAP

text: I then slept and upon awaking I must have returned upon my steps--thus supposing the circuit nearly double what it actually was.
author: EAP

text: My confusion of mind prevented me from observing that I began my tour with the wall to the left and ended it with the wall to the right.
author: EAP

text: I had been deceived too in respect to the shape of the enclosure.
author: EAP

text: In feeling my way I had found many angles and thus deduced an idea of great irregularity; so potent is the effect of total darkness upon one arousing from lethargy or sleep The angles were simply those of a few slight depressions or niches at odd intervals.
author: EAP

text: What I had taken for masonry seemed now to be iron or some other metal in huge plates whose sutures or joints occasioned the depression.
author: EAP

text: The entire surface of this metallic enclosure was rudely daubed in all the hideous and repulsive devices to which the charnel superstition of the monks has given rise.
author: EAP

text: The figures of fiends in aspects of menace with skeleton forms and other more really fearful images overspread and disfigured the walls.
author: EAP

text: I observed that the outlines of these monstrosities were sufficiently distinct but that the colors seemed faded and blurred as if from the effects of a damp atmosphere.
author: EAP

text: I now noticed the floor too which was of stone.
author: EAP

text: In the centre yawned the circular pit from whose jaws I had escaped; but it was the only one in the dungeon.
author: EAP

text: All this I saw indistinctly and by much effort for my personal condition had been greatly changed during slumber.
author: EAP

text: I now lay upon my back and at full length on a species of low framework of wood.
author: EAP

text: To this I was securely bound by a long strap resembling a surcingle.
author: EAP

text: It passed in many convolutions about my limbs and body leaving at liberty only my head and my left arm to such extent that I could by dint of much exertion supply myself with food from an earthen dish which lay by my side on the floor.
author: EAP

text: I saw to my horror that the pitcher had been removed.
author: EAP

text: I say to my horror; for I was consumed with intolerable thirst.
author: EAP

text: This thirst it appeared to be the design of my persecutors to stimulate for the food in the dish was meat pungently seasoned.
author: EAP

text: It was some thirty or forty feet overhead and constructed much as the side walls.
author: EAP

text: In one of its panels a very singular figure riveted my whole attention.
author: EAP

text: It was the painted figure of Time as he is commonly represented save that in lieu of a scythe he held what at a casual glance I supposed to be the pictured image of a huge pendulum such as we see on antique clocks.
author: EAP

text: There was something however in the appearance of this machine which caused me to regard it more attentively.
author: EAP

text: While I gazed directly upward at it for its position was immediately over my own I fancied that I saw it in motion.
author: EAP

text: I watched it for some minutes somewhat in fear but more in wonder.
author: EAP

text: Wearied at length with observing its dull movement I turned my eyes upon the other objects in the cell.
author: EAP

text: A slight noise attracted my notice and looking to the floor I saw several enormous rats traversing it.
author: EAP

text: They had issued from the well which lay just within view to my right.
author: EAP

text: Even then while I gazed they came up in troops hurriedly with ravenous eyes allured by the scent of the meat.
author: EAP

text: From this it required much effort and attention to scare them away.
author: EAP

text: It might have been half an hour perhaps even an hour for I could take but imperfect note of time before I again cast my eyes upward.
author: EAP

text: The sweep of the pendulum had increased in extent by nearly a yard.
author: EAP

text: As a natural consequence its velocity was also much greater.
author: EAP

text: But what mainly disturbed me was the idea that had perceptibly descended.
author: EAP

text: I now observed--with what horror it is needless to say--that its nether extremity was formed of a crescent of glittering steel about a foot in length from horn to horn; the horns upward and the under edge evidently as keen as that of a razor.
author: EAP

text: Like a razor also it seemed massy and heavy tapering from the edge into a solid and broad structure above.
author: EAP

text: It was appended to a weighty rod of brass and the whole hissed as it swung through the air.
author: EAP

text: I could no longer doubt the doom prepared for me by monkish ingenuity in torture.
author: EAP

text: My cognizance of the pit had become known to the inquisitorial agents--the pit whose horrors had been destined for so bold a recusant as myself--the pit typical of hell and regarded by rumor as the Ultima Thule of all their punishments.
author: EAP

text: The plunge into this pit I had avoided by the merest of accidents I knew that surprise or entrapment into torment formed an important portion of all the grotesquerie of these dungeon deaths.
author: EAP

text: Having failed to fall it was no part of the demon plan to hurl me into the abyss; and thus there being no alternative a different and a milder destruction awaited me.
author: EAP

text: Milder I half smiled in my agony as I thought of such application of such a term.
author: EAP

text: What boots it to tell of the long long hours of horror more than mortal during which I counted the rushing vibrations of the steel Inch by inch--line by line--with a descent only appreciable at intervals that seemed ages--down and still down it came Days passed--it might have been that many days passed--ere it swept so closely over me as to fan me with its acrid breath.
author: EAP

text: The odor of the sharp steel forced itself into my nostrils.
author: EAP

text: I prayed--I wearied heaven with my prayer for its more speedy descent.
author: EAP

text: I grew frantically mad and struggled to force myself upward against the sweep of the fearful scimitar.
author: EAP

text: And then I fell suddenly calm and lay smiling at the glittering death as a child at some rare bauble.
author: EAP

text: There was another interval of utter insensibility; it was brief; for upon again lapsing into life there had been no perceptible descent in the pendulum.
author: EAP

text: But it might have been long; for I knew there were demons who took note of my swoon and who could have arrested the vibration at pleasure.
author: EAP

text: Upon my recovery too I felt very--oh inexpressibly sick and weak as if through long inanition.
author: EAP

text: Even amid the agonies of that period the human nature craved food.
author: EAP

text: With painful effort I outstretched my left arm as far as my bonds permitted and took possession of the small remnant which had been spared me by the rats.
author: EAP

text: As I put a portion of it within my lips there rushed to my mind a half formed thought of joy--of hope.
author: EAP

text: Yet what business had I with hope It was as I say a half formed thought--man has many such which are never completed.
author: EAP

text: I felt that it was of joy--of hope; but felt also that it had perished in its formation.
author: EAP

text: Long suffering had nearly annihilated all my ordinary powers of mind.
author: EAP

text: The vibration of the pendulum was at right angles to my length.
author: EAP

text: I saw that the crescent was designed to cross the region of the heart.
author: EAP

text: It would fray the serge of my robe--it would return and repeat its operations--again--and again.
author: EAP

text: Notwithstanding terrifically wide sweep some thirty feet or more and the hissing vigor of its descent sufficient to sunder these very walls of iron still the fraying of my robe would be all that for several minutes it would accomplish.
author: EAP

text: I dwelt upon it with a pertinacity of attention--as if in so dwelling I could arrest here the descent of the steel.
author: EAP

text: I forced myself to ponder upon the sound of the crescent as it should pass across the garment--upon the peculiar thrilling sensation which the friction of cloth produces on the nerves.
author: EAP

text: I pondered upon all this frivolity until my teeth were on edge.
author: EAP

text: I took a frenzied pleasure in contrasting its downward with its lateral velocity.
author: EAP

text: To the right--to the left--far and wide--with the shriek of a damned spirit; to my heart with the stealthy pace of the tiger I alternately laughed and howled as the one or the other idea grew predominant.
author: EAP

text: Down--certainly relentlessly down It vibrated within three inches of my bosom I struggled violently furiously to free my left arm.
author: EAP

text: This was free only from the elbow to the hand.
author: EAP

text: I could reach the latter from the platter beside me to my mouth with great effort but no farther.
author: EAP

text: Could I have broken the fastenings above the elbow I would have seized and attempted to arrest the pendulum.
author: EAP

text: I might as well have attempted to arrest an avalanche  Down--still unceasingly--still inevitably down I gasped and struggled at each vibration.
author: EAP

text: My eyes followed its outward or upward whirls with the eagerness of the most unmeaning despair; they closed themselves spasmodically at the descent although death would have been a relief oh how unspeakable Still I quivered in every nerve to think how slight a sinking of the machinery would precipitate that keen glistening axe upon my bosom.
author: EAP

text: It was hope that prompted the nerve to quiver--the frame to shrink.
author: EAP

text: It was hope--the hope that triumphs on the rack--that whispers to the death-condemned even in the dungeons of the Inquisition.
author: EAP

text: I saw that some ten or twelve vibrations would bring the steel in actual contact with my robe and with this observation there suddenly came over my spirit all the keen collected calmness of despair.
author: EAP

text: For the first time during many hours--or perhaps days--I thought.
author: EAP

text: It now occurred to me that the bandage or surcingle which enveloped me was unique.
author: EAP

text: The first stroke of the razorlike crescent athwart any portion of the band would so detach it that it might be unwound from my person by means of my left hand.
author: EAP

text: But how fearful in that case the proximity of the steel The result of the slightest struggle how deadly Was it likely moreover that the minions of the torturer had not foreseen and provided for this possibility Was it probable that the bandage crossed my bosom in the track of the pendulum Dreading to find my faint and as it seemed my last hope frustrated I so far elevated my head as to obtain a distinct view of my breast.
author: EAP

text: The surcingle enveloped my limbs and body close in all directions--save in the path of the destroying crescent.
author: EAP

text: Scarcely had I dropped my head back into its original position when there flashed upon my mind what I cannot better describe than as the unformed half of that idea of deliverance to which I have previously alluded and of which a moiety only floated indeterminately through my brain when I raised food to my burning lips.
author: EAP

text: The whole thought was now present--feeble scarcely sane scarcely definite--but still entire.
author: EAP

text: I proceeded at once with the nervous energy of despair to attempt its execution.
author: EAP

text: For many hours the immediate vicinity of the low framework upon which I lay had been literally swarming with rats.
author: EAP

text: They were wild bold ravenous; their red eyes glaring upon me as if they waited but for motionlessness on my part to make me their prey.
author: EAP

text: To what food I thought have they been accustomed in the well  They had devoured in spite of all my efforts to prevent them all but a small remnant of the contents of the dish.
author: EAP

text: I had fallen into an habitual see-saw or wave of the hand about the platter and at length the unconscious uniformity of the movement deprived it of effect.
author: EAP

text: In their voracity the vermin frequently fastened their sharp fangs in my fingers.
author: EAP

text: With the particles of the oily and spicy viand which now remained I thoroughly rubbed the bandage wherever I could reach it; then raising my hand from the floor I lay breathlessly still.
author: EAP

text: At first the ravenous animals were startled and terrified at the change--at the cessation of movement.
author: EAP

text: They shrank alarmedly back; many sought the well.
author: EAP

text: Observing that I remained without motion one or two of the boldest leaped upon the frame-work and smelt at the surcingle.
author: EAP

text: Forth from the well they hurried in fresh troops.
author: EAP

text: They clung to the wood--they overran it and leaped in hundreds upon my person.
author: EAP

text: The measured movement of the pendulum disturbed them not at all.
author: EAP

text: Avoiding its strokes they busied themselves with the anointed bandage.
author: EAP

text: They writhed upon my throat; their cold lips sought my own; I was half stifled by their thronging pressure; disgust for which the world has no name swelled my bosom and chilled with a heavy clamminess my heart.
author: EAP

text: Yet one minute and I felt that the struggle would be over.
author: EAP

text: I knew that in more than one place it must be already severed.
author: EAP

text: But the stroke of the pendulum already pressed upon my bosom.
author: EAP

text: Twice again it swung and a sharp sense of pain shot through every nerve.
author: EAP

text: With a steady movement--cautious sidelong shrinking and slow--I slid from the embrace of the bandage and beyond the reach of the scimitar.
author: EAP

text: Free--and in the grasp of the Inquisition I had scarcely stepped from my wooden bed of horror upon the stone floor of the prison when the motion of the hellish machine ceased and I beheld it drawn up by some invisible force through the ceiling.
author: EAP

text: Free--I had but escaped death in one form of agony to be delivered unto worse than death in some other.
author: EAP

text: With that thought I rolled my eves nervously around on the barriers of iron that hemmed me in.
author: EAP

text: Something unusual--some change which at first I could not appreciate distinctly--it was obvious had taken place in the apartment.
author: EAP

text: For many minutes of a dreamy and trembling abstraction I busied myself in vain unconnected conjecture.
author: EAP

text: During this period I became aware for the first time of the origin of the sulphurous light which illumined the cell.
author: EAP

text: It proceeded from a fissure about half an inch in width extending entirely around the prison at the base of the walls which thus appeared and were completely separated from the floor.
author: EAP

text: I endeavored but of course in vain to look through the aperture.
author: EAP

text: As I arose from the attempt the mystery of the alteration in the chamber broke at once upon my understanding.
author: EAP

text: I have observed that although the outlines of the figures upon the walls were sufficiently distinct yet the colors seemed blurred and indefinite.
author: EAP

text: These colors had now assumed and were momentarily assuming a startling and most intense brilliancy that gave to the spectral and fiendish portraitures an aspect that might have thrilled even firmer nerves than my own.
author: EAP

text: Demon eyes of a wild and ghastly vivacity glared upon me in a thousand directions where none had been visible before and gleamed with the lurid lustre of a fire that I could not force my imagination to regard as unreal.
author: EAP

text: Unreal--Even while I breathed there came to my nostrils the breath of the vapour of heated iron A suffocating odour pervaded the prison A deeper glow settled each moment in the eyes that glared at my agonies A richer tint of crimson diffused itself over the pictured horrors of blood.
author: EAP

text: I panted I gasped for breath There could be no doubt of the design of my tormentors--oh most unrelenting oh most demoniac of men I shrank from the glowing metal to the centre of the cell.
author: EAP

text: Amid the thought of the fiery destruction that impended the idea of the coolness of the well came over my soul like balm.
author: EAP

text: The glare from the enkindled roof illumined its inmost recesses.
author: EAP

text: Yet for a wild moment did my spirit refuse to comprehend the meaning of what I saw.
author: EAP

text: At length it forced--it wrestled its way into my soul--it burned itself in upon my shuddering reason.
author: EAP

text: --Oh for a voice to speak--oh horror--oh any horror but this With a shriek I rushed from the margin and buried my face in my hands--weeping bitterly.
author: EAP

text: The heat rapidly increased and once again I looked up shuddering as with a fit of the ague.
author: EAP

text: There had been a second change in the cell--and now the change was obviously in the form.
author: EAP

text: As before it was in vain that I at first endeavoured to appreciate or understand what was taking place.
author: EAP

text: The Inquisitorial vengeance had been hurried by my two-fold escape and there was to be no more dallying with the King of Terrors.
author: EAP

text: I saw that two of its iron angles were now acute--two consequently obtuse.
author: EAP

text: The fearful difference quickly increased with a low rumbling or moaning sound.
author: EAP

text: In an instant the apartment had shifted its form into that of a lozenge.
author: EAP

text: But the alteration stopped not here-I neither hoped nor desired it to stop.
author: EAP

text: I could have clasped the red walls to my bosom as a garment of eternal peace.
author: EAP

text: Death I said any death but that of the pit Fool might I have not known that into the pit it was the object of the burning iron to urge me Could I resist its glow or if even that could I withstand its pressure And now flatter and flatter grew the lozenge with a rapidity that left me no time for contemplation.
author: EAP

text: Its centre and of course its greatest width came just over the yawning gulf.
author: EAP

text: I shrank back--but the closing walls pressed me resistlessly onward.
author: EAP

text: At length for my seared and writhing body there was no longer an inch of foothold on the firm floor of the prison.
author: EAP

text: I struggled no more but the agony of my soul found vent in one loud long and final scream of despair.
author: EAP

text: I felt that I tottered upon the brink--I averted my eyes--  There was a discordant hum of human voices There was a loud blast as of many trumpets There was a harsh grating as of a thousand thunders The fiery walls rushed back An outstretched arm caught my own as I fell fainting into the abyss.
author: EAP

text: THERE are certain themes of which the interest is all-absorbing but which are too entirely horrible for the purposes of legitimate fiction.
author: EAP

text: These the mere romanticist must eschew if he do not wish to offend or to disgust.
author: EAP

text: They are with propriety handled only when the severity and majesty of Truth sanctify and sustain them.
author: EAP

text: We thrill for example with the most intense of pleasurable pain over the accounts of the Passage of the Beresina of the Earthquake at Lisbon of the Plague at London of the Massacre of St. Bartholomew or of the stifling of the hundred and twenty-three prisoners in the Black Hole at Calcutta.
author: EAP

text: But in these accounts it is the fact----it is the reality----it is the history which excites.
author: EAP

text: I have mentioned some few of the more prominent and august calamities on record; but in these it is the extent not less than the character of the calamity which so vividly impresses the fancy.
author: EAP

text: I need not remind the reader that from the long and weird catalogue of human miseries I might have selected many individual instances more replete with essential suffering than any of these vast generalities of disaster.
author: EAP

text: The true wretchedness indeed--the ultimate woe----is particular not diffuse.
author: EAP

text: That the ghastly extremes of agony are endured by man the unit and never by man the mass----for this let us thank a merciful God  To be buried while alive is beyond question the most terrific of these extremes which has ever fallen to the lot of mere mortality.
author: EAP

text: That it has frequently very frequently so fallen will scarcely be denied by those who think.
author: EAP

text: The boundaries which divide Life from Death are at best shadowy and vague.
author: EAP

text: Who shall say where the one ends and where the other begins We know that there are diseases in which occur total cessations of all the apparent functions of vitality and yet in which these cessations are merely suspensions properly so called.
author: EAP

text: They are only temporary pauses in the incomprehensible mechanism.
author: EAP

text: A certain period elapses and some unseen mysterious principle again sets in motion the magic pinions and the wizard wheels.
author: EAP

text: The silver cord was not for ever loosed nor the golden bowl irreparably broken.
author: EAP

text: But where meantime was the soul  Apart however from the inevitable conclusion a priori that such causes must produce such effects----that the well-known occurrence of such cases of suspended animation must naturally give rise now and then to premature interments--apart from this consideration we have the direct testimony of medical and ordinary experience to prove that a vast number of such interments have actually taken place.
author: EAP

text: I might refer at once if necessary to a hundred well authenticated instances.
author: EAP

text: One of very remarkable character and of which the circumstances may be fresh in the memory of some of my readers occurred not very long ago in the neighboring city of Baltimore where it occasioned a painful intense and widely-extended excitement.
author: EAP

text: The wife of one of the most respectable citizens--a lawyer of eminence and a member of Congress--was seized with a sudden and unaccountable illness which completely baffled the skill of her physicians.
author: EAP

text: After much suffering she died or was supposed to die.
author: EAP

text: No one suspected indeed or had reason to suspect that she was not actually dead.
author: EAP

text: The face assumed the usual pinched and sunken outline.
author: EAP

text: For three days the body was preserved unburied during which it had acquired a stony rigidity.
author: EAP

text: The funeral in short was hastened on account of the rapid advance of what was supposed to be decomposition.
author: EAP

text: The lady was deposited in her family vault which for three subsequent years was undisturbed.
author: EAP

text: At the expiration of this term it was opened for the reception of a sarcophagus;----but alas how fearful a shock awaited the husband who personally threw open the door As its portals swung outwardly back some white-apparelled object fell rattling within his arms.
author: EAP

text: It was the skeleton of his wife in her yet unmoulded shroud.
author: EAP

text: A careful investigation rendered it evident that she had revived within two days after her entombment; that her struggles within the coffin had caused it to fall from a ledge or shelf to the floor where it was so broken as to permit her escape.
author: EAP

text: A lamp which had been accidentally left full of oil within the tomb was found empty; it might have been exhausted however by evaporation.
author: EAP

text: On the uttermost of the steps which led down into the dread chamber was a large fragment of the coffin with which it seemed that she had endeavored to arrest attention by striking the iron door.
author: EAP

text: While thus occupied she probably swooned or possibly died through sheer terror; and in failing her shroud became entangled in some iron--work which projected interiorly.
author: EAP

text: Thus she remained and thus she rotted erect.
author: EAP

text: In the year 1810 a case of living inhumation happened in France attended with circumstances which go far to warrant the assertion that truth is indeed stranger than fiction.
author: EAP

text: The heroine of the story was a Mademoiselle Victorine Lafourcade a young girl of illustrious family of wealth and of great personal beauty.
author: EAP

text: Among her numerous suitors was Julien Bossuet a poor litterateur or journalist of Paris.
author: EAP

text: His talents and general amiability had recommended him to the notice of the heiress by whom he seems to have been truly beloved; but her pride of birth decided her finally to reject him and to wed a Monsieur Renelle a banker and a diplomatist of some eminence.
author: EAP

text: After marriage however this gentleman neglected and perhaps even more positively ill-treated her.
author: EAP

text: Having passed with him some wretched years she died----at least her condition so closely resembled death as to deceive every one who saw her.
author: EAP

text: She was buried----not in a vault but in an ordinary grave in the village of her nativity.
author: EAP

text: Filled with despair and still inflamed by the memory of a profound attachment the lover journeys from the capital to the remote province in which the village lies with the romantic purpose of disinterring the corpse and possessing himself of its luxuriant tresses.
author: EAP

text: At midnight he unearths the coffin opens it and is in the act of detaching the hair when he is arrested by the unclosing of the beloved eyes.
author: EAP

text: Vitality had not altogether departed and she was aroused by the caresses of her lover from the lethargy which had been mistaken for death.
author: EAP

text: He employed certain powerful restoratives suggested by no little medical learning.
author: EAP

text: She remained with him until by slow degrees she fully recovered her original health.
author: EAP

text: Her womans heart was not adamant and this last lesson of love sufficed to soften it.
author: EAP

text: She returned no more to her husband but concealing from him her resurrection fled with her lover to America.
author: EAP

text: Twenty years afterward the two returned to France in the persuasion that time had so greatly altered the ladys appearance that her friends would be unable to recognize her.
author: EAP

text: They were mistaken however for at the first meeting Monsieur Renelle did actually recognize and make claim to his wife.
author: EAP

text: This claim she resisted and a judicial tribunal sustained her in her resistance deciding that the peculiar circumstances with the long lapse of years had extinguished not only equitably but legally the authority of the husband.
author: EAP

text: The Chirurgical Journal of Leipsic--a periodical of high authority and merit which some American bookseller would do well to translate and republish records in a late number a very distressing event of the character in question.
author: EAP

text: An officer of artillery a man of gigantic stature and of robust health being thrown from an unmanageable horse received a very severe contusion upon the head which rendered him insensible at once; the skull was slightly fractured but no immediate danger was apprehended.
author: EAP

text: He was bled and many other of the ordinary means of relief were adopted.
author: EAP

text: Gradually however he fell into a more and more hopeless state of stupor and finally it was thought that he died.
author: EAP

text: The weather was warm and he was buried with indecent haste in one of the public cemeteries.
author: EAP

text: On the Sunday following the grounds of the cemetery were as usual much thronged with visiters and about noon an intense excitement was created by the declaration of a peasant that while sitting upon the grave of the officer he had distinctly felt a commotion of the earth as if occasioned by some one struggling beneath.
author: EAP

text: At first little attention was paid to the mans asseveration; but his evident terror and the dogged obstinacy with which he persisted in his story had at length their natural effect upon the crowd.
author: EAP

text: Spades were hurriedly procured and the grave which was shamefully shallow was in a few minutes so far thrown open that the head of its occupant appeared.
author: EAP

text: He was then seemingly dead; but he sat nearly erect within his coffin the lid of which in his furious struggles he had partially uplifted.
author: EAP

text: He was forthwith conveyed to the nearest hospital and there pronounced to be still living although in an asphytic condition.
author: EAP

text: After some hours he revived recognized individuals of his acquaintance and in broken sentences spoke of his agonies in the grave.
author: EAP

text: From what he related it was clear that he must have been conscious of life for more than an hour while inhumed before lapsing into insensibility.
author: EAP

text: The grave was carelessly and loosely filled with an exceedingly porous soil; and thus some air was necessarily admitted.
author: EAP

text: He heard the footsteps of the crowd overhead and endeavored to make himself heard in turn.
author: EAP

text: It was the tumult within the grounds of the cemetery he said which appeared to awaken him from a deep sleep but no sooner was he awake than he became fully aware of the awful horrors of his position.
author: EAP

text: This patient it is recorded was doing well and seemed to be in a fair way of ultimate recovery but fell a victim to the quackeries of medical experiment.
author: EAP

text: The galvanic battery was applied and he suddenly expired in one of those ecstatic paroxysms which occasionally it superinduces.
author: EAP

text: The mention of the galvanic battery nevertheless recalls to my memory a well known and very extraordinary case in point where its action proved the means of restoring to animation a young attorney of London who had been interred for two days.
author: EAP

text: This occurred in 1831 and created at the time a very profound sensation wherever it was made the subject of converse.
author: EAP

text: The patient Mr. Edward Stapleton had died apparently of typhus fever accompanied with some anomalous symptoms which had excited the curiosity of his medical attendants.
author: EAP

text: Upon his seeming decease his friends were requested to sanction a post-mortem examination but declined to permit it.
author: EAP

text: As often happens when such refusals are made the practitioners resolved to disinter the body and dissect it at leisure in private.
author: EAP

text: Arrangements were easily effected with some of the numerous corps of body-snatchers with which London abounds; and upon the third night after the funeral the supposed corpse was unearthed from a grave eight feet deep and deposited in the opening chamber of one of the private hospitals.
author: EAP

text: An incision of some extent had been actually made in the abdomen when the fresh and undecayed appearance of the subject suggested an application of the battery.
author: EAP

text: One experiment succeeded another and the customary effects supervened with nothing to characterize them in any respect except upon one or two occasions a more than ordinary degree of life-likeness in the convulsive action.
author: EAP

text: The day was about to dawn; and it was thought expedient at length to proceed at once to the dissection.
author: EAP

text: A student however was especially desirous of testing a theory of his own and insisted upon applying the battery to one of the pectoral muscles.
author: EAP

text: A rough gash was made and a wire hastily brought in contact when the patient with a hurried but quite unconvulsive movement arose from the table stepped into the middle of the floor gazed about him uneasily for a few seconds and then--spoke. What he said was unintelligible but words were uttered; the syllabification was distinct.
author: EAP

text: For some moments all were paralyzed with awe--but the urgency of the case soon restored them their presence of mind.
author: EAP

text: It was seen that Mr. Stapleton was alive although in a swoon.
author: EAP

text: Upon exhibition of ether he revived and was rapidly restored to health and to the society of his friends--from whom however all knowledge of his resuscitation was withheld until a relapse was no longer to be apprehended.
author: EAP

text: The most thrilling peculiarity of this incident nevertheless is involved in what Mr. S. himself asserts.
author: EAP

text: He declares that at no period was he altogether insensible--that dully and confusedly he was aware of everything which happened to him from the moment in which he was pronounced dead by his physicians to that in which he fell swooning to the floor of the hospital.
author: EAP

text: I am alive were the uncomprehended words which upon recognizing the locality of the dissecting-room he had endeavored in his extremity to utter.
author: EAP

text: It were an easy matter to multiply such histories as these--but I forbear--for indeed we have no need of such to establish the fact that premature interments occur.
author: EAP

text: When we reflect how very rarely from the nature of the case we have it in our power to detect them we must admit that they may frequently occur without our cognizance.
author: EAP

text: Scarcely in truth is a graveyard ever encroached upon for any purpose to any great extent that skeletons are not found in postures which suggest the most fearful of suspicions.
author: EAP

text: Fearful indeed the suspicion--but more fearful the doom It may be asserted without hesitation that no event is so terribly well adapted to inspire the supremeness of bodily and of mental distress as is burial before death.
author: EAP

text: The unendurable oppression of the lungs--the stifling fumes from the damp earth--the clinging to the death garments--the rigid embrace of the narrow house--the blackness of the absolute Night--the silence like a sea that overwhelms--the unseen but palpable presence of the Conqueror Worm--these things with the thoughts of the air and grass above with memory of dear friends who would fly to save us if but informed of our fate and with consciousness that of this fate they can never be informed--that our hopeless portion is that of the really dead--these considerations I say carry into the heart which still palpitates a degree of appalling and intolerable horror from which the most daring imagination must recoil.
author: EAP

text: We know of nothing so agonizing upon Earth--we can dream of nothing half so hideous in the realms of the nethermost Hell.
author: EAP

text: And thus all narratives upon this topic have an interest profound; an interest nevertheless which through the sacred awe of the topic itself very properly and very peculiarly depends upon our conviction of the truth of the matter narrated.
author: EAP

text: What I have now to tell is of my own actual knowledge--of my own positive and personal experience.
author: EAP

text: For several years I had been subject to attacks of the singular disorder which physicians have agreed to term catalepsy in default of a more definitive title.
author: EAP

text: Although both the immediate and the predisposing causes and even the actual diagnosis of this disease are still mysterious its obvious and apparent character is sufficiently well understood.
author: EAP

text: Sometimes the patient lies for a day only or even for a shorter period in a species of exaggerated lethargy.
author: EAP

text: He is senseless and externally motionless; but the pulsation of the heart is still faintly perceptible; some traces of warmth remain; a slight color lingers within the centre of the cheek; and upon application of a mirror to the lips we can detect a torpid unequal and vacillating action of the lungs.
author: EAP

text: Then again the duration of the trance is for weeks--even for months; while the closest scrutiny and the most rigorous medical tests fail to establish any material distinction between the state of the sufferer and what we conceive of absolute death.
author: EAP

text: Very usually he is saved from premature interment solely by the knowledge of his friends that he has been previously subject to catalepsy by the consequent suspicion excited and above all by the non-appearance of decay.
author: EAP

text: The fits grow successively more and more distinctive and endure each for a longer term than the preceding.
author: EAP

text: The unfortunate whose first attack should be of the extreme character which is occasionally seen would almost inevitably be consigned alive to the tomb.
author: EAP

text: My own case differed in no important particular from those mentioned in medical books.
author: EAP

text: Sometimes without any apparent cause I sank little by little into a condition of hemi-syncope or half swoon; and in this condition without pain without ability to stir or strictly speaking to think but with a dull lethargic consciousness of life and of the presence of those who surrounded my bed I remained until the crisis of the disease restored me suddenly to perfect sensation.
author: EAP

text: I grew sick and numb and chilly and dizzy and so fell prostrate at once.
author: EAP

text: Then for weeks all was void and black and silent and Nothing became the universe.
author: EAP

text: From these latter attacks I awoke however with a gradation slow in proportion to the suddenness of the seizure.
author: EAP

text: Just as the day dawns to the friendless and houseless beggar who roams the streets throughout the long desolate winter night--just so tardily--just so wearily--just so cheerily came back the light of the Soul to me.
author: EAP

text: Apart from the tendency to trance however my general health appeared to be good; nor could I perceive that it was at all affected by the one prevalent malady--unless indeed an idiosyncrasy in my ordinary sleep may be looked upon as superinduced.
author: EAP

text: Upon awaking from slumber I could never gain at once thorough possession of my senses and always remained for many minutes in much bewilderment and perplexity;--the mental faculties in general but the memory in especial being in a condition of absolute abeyance.
author: EAP

text: In all that I endured there was no physical suffering but of moral distress an infinitude.
author: EAP

text: My fancy grew charnel I talked of worms of tombs and epitaphs.
author: EAP

text: I was lost in reveries of death and the idea of premature burial held continual possession of my brain.
author: EAP

text: The ghastly Danger to which I was subjected haunted me day and night.
author: EAP

text: In the former the torture of meditation was excessive--in the latter supreme.
author: EAP

text: When the grim Darkness overspread the Earth then with every horror of thought I shook--shook as the quivering plumes upon the hearse.
author: EAP

text: When Nature could endure wakefulness no longer it was with a struggle that I consented to sleep--for I shuddered to reflect that upon awaking I might find myself the tenant of a grave.
author: EAP

text: And when finally I sank into slumber it was only to rush at once into a world of phantasms above which with vast sable overshadowing wing hovered predominant the one sepulchral Idea.
author: EAP

text: From the innumerable images of gloom which thus oppressed me in dreams I select for record but a solitary vision.
author: EAP

text: Methought I was immersed in a cataleptic trance of more than usual duration and profundity.
author: EAP

text: Suddenly there came an icy hand upon my forehead and an impatient gibbering voice whispered the word Arise within my ear.
author: EAP

text: I could not see the figure of him who had aroused me.
author: EAP

text: I could call to mind neither the period at which I had fallen into the trance nor the locality in which I then lay.
author: EAP

text: While I remained motionless and busied in endeavors to collect my thought the cold hand grasped me fiercely by the wrist shaking it petulantly while the gibbering voice said again  Arise did I not bid thee arise  And who I demanded art thou  I have no name in the regions which I inhabit replied the voice mournfully; I was mortal but am fiend.
author: EAP

text: --My teeth chatter as I speak yet it is not with the chilliness of the night--of the night without end.
author: EAP

text: How canst thou tranquilly sleep I cannot rest for the cry of these great agonies.
author: EAP

text: Get thee up Come with me into the outer Night and let me unfold to thee the graves.
author: EAP

text: Is not this a spectacle of woe--Behold  I looked; and the unseen figure which still grasped me by the wrist had caused to be thrown open the graves of all mankind and from each issued the faint phosphoric radiance of decay so that I could see into the innermost recesses and there view the shrouded bodies in their sad and solemn slumbers with the worm.
author: EAP

text: But alas the real sleepers were fewer by many millions than those who slumbered not at all; and there was a feeble struggling; and there was a general sad unrest; and from out the depths of the countless pits there came a melancholy rustling from the garments of the buried.
author: EAP

text: And of those who seemed tranquilly to repose I saw that a vast number had changed in a greater or less degree the rigid and uneasy position in which they had originally been entombed.
author: EAP

text: And the voice again said to me as I gazed  Is it not--oh is it not a pitiful sight--but before I could find words to reply the figure had ceased to grasp my wrist the phosphoric lights expired and the graves were closed with a sudden violence while from out them arose a tumult of despairing cries saying again Is it not--O God is it not a very pitiful sight  Phantasies such as these presenting themselves at night extended their terrific influence far into my waking hours.
author: EAP

text: My nerves became thoroughly unstrung and I fell a prey to perpetual horror.
author: EAP

text: I hesitated to ride or to walk or to indulge in any exercise that would carry me from home.
author: EAP

text: In fact I no longer dared trust myself out of the immediate presence of those who were aware of my proneness to catalepsy lest falling into one of my usual fits I should be buried before my real condition could be ascertained.
author: EAP

text: I dreaded that in some trance of more than customary duration they might be prevailed upon to regard me as irrecoverable.
author: EAP

text: I even went so far as to fear that as I occasioned much trouble they might be glad to consider any very protracted attack as sufficient excuse for getting rid of me altogether.
author: EAP

text: It was in vain they endeavored to reassure me by the most solemn promises.
author: EAP

text: I exacted the most sacred oaths that under no circumstances they would bury me until decomposition had so materially advanced as to render farther preservation impossible.
author: EAP

text: And even then my mortal terrors would listen to no reason--would accept no consolation.
author: EAP

text: Among other things I had the family vault so remodelled as to admit of being readily opened from within.
author: EAP

text: The slightest pressure upon a long lever that extended far into the tomb would cause the iron portal to fly back.
author: EAP

text: There were arrangements also for the free admission of air and light and convenient receptacles for food and water within immediate reach of the coffin intended for my reception.
author: EAP

text: This coffin was warmly and softly padded and was provided with a lid fashioned upon the principle of the vault-door with the addition of springs so contrived that the feeblest movement of the body would be sufficient to set it at liberty.
author: EAP

text: Besides all this there was suspended from the roof of the tomb a large bell the rope of which it was designed should extend through a hole in the coffin and so be fastened to one of the hands of the corpse.
author: EAP

text: But alas what avails the vigilance against the Destiny of man Not even these well-contrived securities sufficed to save from the uttermost agonies of living inhumation a wretch to these agonies foredoomed  There arrived an epoch--as often before there had arrived--in which I found myself emerging from total unconsciousness into the first feeble and indefinite sense of existence.
author: EAP

text: Slowly--with a tortoise gradation--approached the faint gray dawn of the psychal day.
author: EAP

text: Then after a long interval a ringing in the ears; then after a lapse still longer a prickling or tingling sensation in the extremities; then a seemingly eternal period of pleasurable quiescence during which the awakening feelings are struggling into thought; then a brief re-sinking into non-entity; then a sudden recovery.
author: EAP

text: At length the slight quivering of an eyelid and immediately thereupon an electric shock of a terror deadly and indefinite which sends the blood in torrents from the temples to the heart.
author: EAP

text: And now the memory has so far regained its dominion that in some measure I am cognizant of my state.
author: EAP

text: And now at last as if by the rush of an ocean my shuddering spirit is overwhelmed by the one grim Danger--by the one spectral and ever-prevalent idea.
author: EAP

text: For some minutes after this fancy possessed me I remained without motion.
author: EAP

text: I dared not make the effort which was to satisfy me of my fate--and yet there was something at my heart which whispered me it was sure.
author: EAP

text: Despair--such as no other species of wretchedness ever calls into being--despair alone urged me after long irresolution to uplift the heavy lids of my eyes.
author: EAP

text: I knew that the crisis of my disorder had long passed.
author: EAP

text: I knew that I had now fully recovered the use of my visual faculties--and yet it was dark--all dark--the intense and utter raylessness of the Night that endureth for evermore.
author: EAP

text: I endeavored to shriek; and my lips and my parched tongue moved convulsively together in the attempt--but no voice issued from the cavernous lungs which oppressed as if by the weight of some incumbent mountain gasped and palpitated with the heart at every elaborate and struggling inspiration.
author: EAP

text: The movement of the jaws in this effort to cry aloud showed me that they were bound up as is usual with the dead.
author: EAP

text: I felt too that I lay upon some hard substance and by something similar my sides were also closely compressed.
author: EAP

text: So far I had not ventured to stir any of my limbs--but now I violently threw up my arms which had been lying at length with the wrists crossed.
author: EAP

text: They struck a solid wooden substance which extended above my person at an elevation of not more than six inches from my face.
author: EAP

text: I could no longer doubt that I reposed within a coffin at last.
author: EAP

text: And now amid all my infinite miseries came sweetly the cherub Hope--for I thought of my precautions.
author: EAP

text: I writhed and made spasmodic exertions to force open the lid it would not move.
author: EAP

text: I felt my wrists for the bell-rope it was not to be found.
author: EAP

text: And now the Comforter fled for ever and a still sterner Despair reigned triumphant; for I could not help perceiving the absence of the paddings which I had so carefully prepared--and then too there came suddenly to my nostrils the strong peculiar odor of moist earth.
author: EAP

text: I had fallen into a trance while absent from home--while among strangers--when or how I could not remember--and it was they who had buried me as a dog--nailed up in some common coffin--and thrust deep deep and for ever into some ordinary and nameless grave.
author: EAP

text: As this awful conviction forced itself thus into the innermost chambers of my soul I once again struggled to cry aloud.
author: EAP

text: A long wild and continuous shriek or yell of agony resounded through the realms of the subterranean Night.
author: EAP

text: What the devils the matter now said a second.
author: EAP

text: What do you mean by yowling in that ere kind of style like a cattymount said a fourth; and hereupon I was seized and shaken without ceremony for several minutes by a junto of very rough-looking individuals.
author: EAP

text: They did not arouse me from my slumber--for I was wide awake when I screamed--but they restored me to the full possession of my memory.
author: EAP

text: Accompanied by a friend I had proceeded upon a gunning expedition some miles down the banks of the James River.
author: EAP

text: The cabin of a small sloop lying at anchor in the stream and laden with garden mould afforded us the only available shelter.
author: EAP

text: We made the best of it and passed the night on board.
author: EAP

text: I slept in one of the only two berths in the vessel--and the berths of a sloop of sixty or twenty tons need scarcely be described.
author: EAP

text: The distance of its bottom from the deck overhead was precisely the same.
author: EAP

text: Nevertheless I slept soundly and the whole of my vision--for it was no dream and no nightmare--arose naturally from the circumstances of my position--from my ordinary bias of thought--and from the difficulty to which I have alluded of collecting my senses and especially of regaining my memory for a long time after awaking from slumber.
author: EAP

text: The men who shook me were the crew of the sloop and some laborers engaged to unload it.
author: EAP

text: From the load itself came the earthly smell.
author: EAP

text: The bandage about the jaws was a silk handkerchief in which I had bound up my head in default of my customary nightcap.
author: EAP

text: The tortures endured however were indubitably quite equal for the time to those of actual sepulture.
author: EAP

text: They were fearfully--they were inconceivably hideous; but out of Evil proceeded Good; for their very excess wrought in my spirit an inevitable revulsion.
author: EAP

text: I read no Night Thoughts--no fustian about churchyards--no bugaboo tales--such as this.
author: EAP

text: In short I became a new man and lived a mans life.
author: EAP

text: From that memorable night I dismissed forever my charnel apprehensions and with them vanished the cataleptic disorder of which perhaps they had been less the consequence than the cause.
author: EAP

text: There are moments when even to the sober eye of Reason the world of our sad Humanity may assume the semblance of a Hell--but the imagination of man is no Carathis to explore with impunity its every cavern.
author: EAP

text: Alas the grim legion of sepulchral terrors cannot be regarded as altogether fanciful--but like the Demons in whose company Afrasiab made his voyage down the Oxus they must sleep or they will devour us--they must be suffered to slumber or we perish.
author: EAP

text: The garden like a lady fair was cut That lay as if she slumbered in delight And to the open skies her eyes did shut.
author: EAP

text: The azure fields of Heaven were sembled right In a large round set with the flowers of light.
author: EAP

text: The flowers de luce and the round sparks of dew.
author: EAP

text: That hung upon their azure leaves did shew Like twinkling stars that sparkle in the evening blue.
author: EAP

text: FROM his cradle to his grave a gale of prosperity bore my friend Ellison along.
author: EAP

text: Nor do I use the word prosperity in its mere worldly sense.
author: EAP

text: The person of whom I speak seemed born for the purpose of foreshadowing the doctrines of Turgot Price Priestley and Condorcet--of exemplifying by individual instance what has been deemed the chimera of the perfectionists.
author: EAP

text: In the brief existence of Ellison I fancy that I have seen refuted the dogma that in mans very nature lies some hidden principle the antagonist of bliss.
author: EAP

text: An anxious examination of his career has given me to understand that in general from the violation of a few simple laws of humanity arises the wretchedness of mankind--that as a species we have in our possession the as yet unwrought elements of content--and that even now in the present darkness and madness of all thought on the great question of the social condition it is not impossible that man the individual under certain unusual and highly fortuitous conditions may be happy.
author: EAP

text: With opinions such as these my young friend too was fully imbued and thus it is worthy of observation that the uninterrupted enjoyment which distinguished his life was in great measure the result of preconcert.
author: EAP

text: It is indeed evident that with less of the instinctive philosophy which now and then stands so well in the stead of experience Mr. Ellison would have found himself precipitated by the very extraordinary success of his life into the common vortex of unhappiness which yawns for those of pre-eminent endowments.
author: EAP

text: He admitted but four elementary principles or more strictly conditions of bliss.
author: EAP

text: That which he considered chief was strange to say the simple and purely physical one of free exercise in the open air.
author: EAP

text: The health he said attainable by other means is scarcely worth the name.
author: EAP

text: He instanced the ecstasies of the fox-hunter and pointed to the tillers of the earth the only people who as a class can be fairly considered happier than others.
author: EAP

text: His third and most difficult of realization was the contempt of ambition.
author: EAP

text: His fourth was an object of unceasing pursuit; and he held that other things being equal the extent of attainable happiness was in proportion to the spirituality of this object.
author: EAP

text: Ellison was remarkable in the continuous profusion of good gifts lavished upon him by fortune.
author: EAP

text: His intellect was of that order to which the acquisition of knowledge is less a labor than an intuition and a necessity.
author: EAP

text: His family was one of the most illustrious of the empire.
author: EAP

text: His bride was the loveliest and most devoted of women.
author: EAP
